The math behind it Is this really possible? Bitcoin needs to grow at a rate of 0.484095526 % per day from 2017-07-17 to 2020-12-31 to get from $ 2,244.27 to $ 1,000,000.00. That is the red line on the above chart. As long as the blue line is above the red line, we are on target. Hover over the chart to get daily prices. Compared to the enormous price changes, half a percent does not sound like much to you? This is the magic of exponential growth. That parabolic curve - seriously? When you zoom out, the curve gets steeper and steeper. Relax! Growth curves look like that. Take the Dow Jones, a savings account with interest or bacteria growing in a petri dish. With a fixed percentage per time, rising from 1 to 10 takes as long as from 100,000 to 1,000,000. Both is the growth by a factor of 10. That is why many analysts like to look at charts with a logarithmic scale where the y-axis scales in orders of magnitude. Why would it grow? Bitcoin is scarce. There will only be 21 Million BTC. If every Millionaire in the world wants one, there are not enough for every one to have a whole BTC. More people adopting and buying bitcoin will raise the price. This technology is still at a relatively early stage. Think the internet in the mid-nineties when the majority thought it was only for nerds and had no real use. The market capitalization of bitcoin is still tiny, compared to gold, credit cards or the stock market. Such an expensive currency! You can buy and spend fractions of a bitcoin. Sooner or later, it will make sense to use a unit like microbitcoin aka bits (One Millionth of a Bitcoin) and Satoshis (One hundredth of a bit). Then a bit will be a Dollar and a Satoshi will be a Cent. How does something like '1 μBTC is $ 1.07'or '1 Satoshi is $ 0.01' sound to you? A lot less expensive, right? Maybe people will start calling a microbitcoin just bitcoin. No big deal. When we say calorie, we actually mean a kilocalorie. What can go wrong? Though bitcoin has proven to be secure and many people put their trust in it, there is still a lot that can go wrong. Do not invest more than you can afford to lose! Bitcoin could go to zero and many people think so. Is bitcoin wasting electricity? Mining bitcoin is hard on purpose. The so called proof of work is what controls the money supply and what makes the ledger tamper resistant. Bitcoin is both a currency and a ledger for storing all transactions. Gold would not have much value if it were easy to find or if it were cheap to create. A ledger that was easy to tamper with would not be trustworthy. The bitcoin ledger is called blockchain and the entries are bundled into so called blocks. Supercomputers all over the world are competing to find the next block. All these miners do not trust each other and reject invalid blocks. Someone trying to tamper with the blockchain would need an incredible amount of computing power and electricity to overpower all the others. What about CO2 -emissions? Many miners are located in places with a surplus of electricity (geothermal power in Iceland, hydroelectric or solar power in the middle of nowhere). It is cheaper to send a bitcoin-block over the internet than building more power lines. Still not convinced? Think for a minute how complicated the current fiat banking system is and you will agree that bitcoin is a lot more efficient.

While I completely understand the allure of being able to foretell the future, either accurately, approximately or in any manner at all, I am not sure why people would believe that it can actually be done! Somewhere along the way, many aspiring traders have come to believe that “when you know what you are doing”, you can predict the future of how a stock, a currency, or a commodity will perform. Think about it for a minute… …while I have a pretty fair idea of what I will be doing tomorrow, next week, next month, etc., the proverbial “monkey wrench” can mess up my best made plans. I could get sick, the car could break down and, since I live in Minnesota, I can’t begin to count the number of times when a blizzard screwed up my day…and the list goes on. And this is in my own life … where I really have a lot of control. How about in the financial markets? Where I have absolutely NO control! Prediction? Not a chance… The above being said, here is my response, which I have posted before, to questions such as these… Plug in your market instrument of choice…Bitcoin, Oil, Gold, S&P 500, pork bellies… So, you want to know if an event in the future - the gain/crash of Bitcoin in this case - is going to happen? And, you want to know not only if it is going to gain/crash, but also the year in which it will gain/crash…2020 in this case. That’s a pretty tall order!! Here’s a favorite quote of mine on this topic… “Predicting is very difficult…especially when it involves the future.” Traders and mankind in general have been trying to foretell the future - accurately - since time immemorial. I am sure there was some cave man out there trying to predict the migration patterns of the woolly mammoth so his family would know where their next meal was coming from!! Traders, economists, market gurus, etc., can make all kinds of fancy prognostications about if this happens, then that will happen and various currency pairs, commodities, or cryptocurrencies will do this, that and the other thing. Bottom Line: No one knows anything that will happen in the future with any certainty. There is no crystal ball. Sure, some educated guesses can be made but that’s precisely what they are - GUESSES!! The educated guesses may tilt the odds of success in one direction or another, but again, nothing is an absolute “lock”. Unquestionably there are many opinions on how to trade news events/announcements, price action and each trader can decide which is best for them. The school of thought to which I subscribe centers around this quote: “Nothing happens until it happens.”So my trading plan is not to try and predict what may happen; but rather, react to what is happening. In a nutshell, wait until an event takes place - if Bitcoin crashes, let it crash…if it doesn’t, it doesn’t. Then, let the volatility occur and let the market react and kind of shake itself out a bit as it absorbs and interprets the news. Then, when a continuation move (trend) presents itself on your chart time frame of choice, a higher probability trade can be made. In my opinion this affords the trader a much greater chance of success as opposed to trying to predict a move ahead of time. Sure you may miss out on the initial (riskier) part of the move, but the potential for success is increased beyond that of a mere coin flip… Please let me know if you have any questions on the above or other aspects of trading the FX market… All the best and good trading, Richard Krivo RKrivoFX@gmail.com Please visit my YouTube channel at… Richard Krivo

“What is a predicted or projected high for Bitcoin in 2020?” Personally, I find questions that ask “what is the high” or “what will the highest value” of bitcoin be, to be disturbing, because those questions come with some huge and improper assumptions — such as:the assumption that bitcoin should be measured in terms of its value or worth to another currency. (It should not be, though it may be when it is traded on open markets — but this price is always whatever the markets will allow, as the different prices across exchanges demonstrate, especially with variability in supply and liquidity.)the assumption that bitcoin should be measured in terms of its value in relation to USD by default, or the EUR. This is often an implicit assumption with such questions about “prices” or “highs” and it is unfortunate to see such a strong focus on fiat currency valuations of cryptosystems used as currency. With some work, we can largely discard this focus and choose better ways of worth (a difficult, but not impossible challenge).The question asks, “What is a predicted or projected high for Bitcoin in 2020?” The term Bitcoin (with a B) refers to usage of the protocol -- the protocol, payment network, and ecosystem as a whole, whereas bitcoin (with a b) refers to units of currency. Given that the question asks what the projected high for Bitcoin will be in 2020, the proper answer is not related to price of currency (and thus should not be expressed as “price in USD” or other currency), but rather is derived from the innovations we will see in 2020 from the Bitcoin world. These include, in part:Taproot, Schnorr, and related privacy initiatives which will increase efficiency while making most transactions look alike.Solutions based entirely on Bitcoin that are designed expressly to solve ownership and income problems in society (see Reference item (2)).Smart contract advancements based in part upon code which has long been present in Bitcoin but which only recently has been made light of by a larger development community.An interested institutional and legislative community which in some states (following Wyoming's example) will develop (USA) state laws (and potentially work to improve some of the more troublesome federal ones) so as to make the legal landscape more welcoming for innovators and developers.A substantially higher degree of mobile adoption across Latin America and Africa.Projects such as Lightning (lnd), distinct from Bitcoin but helpful to it, will help drive adoption. In 2020, such value adds will continue with sidechain developments that allow atomic cross-chain trading, thus eventually reducing the need individuals will have for customary trading methods online.Bitcoin now finds itself (via the Blockstream satellite system, and the SpaceChain system) broadcast through space. These are a few of the censorship-resistance methods which are now already existing in 2020. The future will see this envelope pushed even further as the nascent Bitcoin protocol escapes terrene boundaries entirely while also eventually being managed by purposeful A.I.s (artificial intelligence units) whose role it will be to propagate and defend the transmittal of the data.As a standard for measurement of Bitcoin worth: for 2020, I have suggested that the value of Bitcoin is equivalent to new usage (both new users and innovation leading to new uses of Bitcoin) and that increases in adoption of bitcoin and other cryptocurrency shall also provide an indicator of value, independent of comparisons to fiat. References: Colin Gallagher's answer to What do you think is the future of cryptocurrency 30 years from now?Colin Gallagher's answer to Which emerging technology are you most excited about?Colin Gallagher's answer to What will Bitcoins be worth in 2020?
